abstract.text: We report the first observation of B ± → ψ(2S)π ± , a Cabibbo-and color-suppressed decay.
This analysis is based on 657 × 10 6 BB events collected at the Υ(4S) resonance with the Belle detector at the KEKB energy-asymmetric e + e − collider.
The measured branching fraction is (2.44 ± 0.22 ± 0.20)×10 −5 and the charge asymmetry is A = 0.022 ± 0.085 ± 0.016.
The ratio of the branching fractions B(B ± → ψ(2S)π ± )/B(B ± → ψ(2S)K ± ) = (3.99 ± 0.36 ± 0.17)% is also determined.

body_text.text: The study of exclusive B meson decays to charmonium has played an important role in exploring CPviolation [1].

Among these, Cabibbo-suppressed charmonium decays provide an opportunity to understand nonleptonic B decays [2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9] and can be studied at the B factories which, due to their high integrated luminosities, overcome the suppression factor.

At quark level, the decay B − → ψ(2S)π − [10] proceeds primarily via a b → ccd transition; the leading contribution to this decay comes from the Cabibbo-and color-suppressed tree diagram shown in Fig. 1.
The measurement of the branching fraction for the decay B − → ψ(2S)π − , which has not been observed so far, is important for detailed studies of the b → ccd transition.
Assuming tree dominance and factorization, the branching fraction B(B − → ψ(2S)π − ) is expected to be about 5% of that of the Cabibbo-favoured mode B − → ψ(2S)K − [11].
Under this assumption, the charge asymmetries for the B − → ψ(2S)π − and B − → ψ(2S)K − decays are expected to be negligibly small in the standard model.

However, the penguin amplitude in the b → ccd transition contains a complex phase due to one of the Kobayashi-Maskawa matrix elements [12], V td , and therefore, if penguin or new physics contributions are substantial, direct CP violation may occur in B − → ψ(2S)π − [13,14].
In this paper, we report the first observation of the B − → ψ(2S)π − decay, along with a measurement of the branching fractions B(B − → ψ(2S)π − ) and the ratio
is also presented.

These measurements are based on a data sample that contains 657 × 10 6 BB events, collected with the Belle detector [15] at the KEKB [16] energy-asymmetric e + e − collider operating at the Υ(4S) resonance.

The Belle detector is a large solid-angle magnetic spectrometer that consists of a silicon vertex detector (SVD) surrounded by a 50-layer central drift chamber (CDC), an array of aerogel threshold Cherenkov counters (ACC), a barrel-like arrangement of time-of-flight (TOF) scintillation counters, and an electromagnetic calorimeter (ECL) comprised of CsI(Tl) crystals.
All these subdetectors are located inside a superconducting solenoid coil that provides a 1.5 T magnetic field.
An iron flux-return yoke located outside the coil is instrumented to detect K 0 L mesons and to identify the muons (KLM).
The data sample used in this analysis is collected with two different detector configurations.

The first sample of 152 × 10 6 BB events is collected with a 2.0 cm radius beam-pipe and a 3-layer SVD, while the remaining 505 × 10 6 BB events are collected with a 1.5 cm radius beam-pipe, a 4-layer SVD and a smaller-cell inner drift chamber [17].
The detector is described in detail elsewhere [15].
A GEANTbased Monte Carlo (MC) simulation is used to model the response of the detector and determine the efficiency of the signal reconstruction [18,19].
The reconstruction of the ψ(2S) meson is performed using the ℓ + ℓ − (ℓ = e or µ) and J/ψπ + π − decay channels.
The J/ψ mesons are reconstructed in the ℓ + ℓ − decay channel.
Both daughter tracks of J/ψ → ℓ + ℓ − or ψ(2S) → ℓ + ℓ − decays are required to be positively identified as leptons.

From the selected charged tracks, e + and e − candidates are identified by combining information from the CDC (dE/dx), E/p (E is the energy deposited in the ECL and p is the momentum measured by the SVD and the CDC), and shower shape in the ECL.
In addition, ACC information and position matching between electron track candidates and ECL clusters are used in the identification of electron candidates.
Identification of µ candidates is based on the track penetration depth and hit pattern in the KLM system.

In J/ψ → e + e − and ψ(2S) → e + e − decays, the fourmomenta of all photons within 50 mrad of each of the original e + or e − tracks are included in the invariant mass calculation [hereafter denoted as M e + e − (γ) ], in order to reduce the radiative tail.

A mass-and vertex-constrained fit is performed to all the selected ψ(2S) and J/ψ candidates in order to improve the momentum resolution.
We combine ψ(2S) and π − (K − ) mesons to form B meson candidates.
The combined information from the CDC (dE/dx), TOF and ACC is used to identify π − (K − ) on the basis of the π − K likelihood ratio,

Charged tracks with R π > 0.85 (R K > 0.85) are identified as π − (K − ).
This requirement is 88.0% (82.6%) efficient for π (K) with a K (π) fake rate of 6.0% (3.7%).
To discriminate the signal from background, we use two kinematic variables: the beam-constrained mass,

beam − p * 2 B and the energy difference, ∆E ≡ E * B − E * beam to discriminate the signal from the background, where E * beam is the run-dependent beam energy, and E * B and p * B are the reconstructed energy and momentum, respectively, of the B meson candidates in the center-of-mass (CM) frame.
We retain B candidates with 5.27 GeV/c 2 < M bc < 5.29 GeV/c 2 and −0.15 GeV < ∆E < 0.2 GeV.
After all selection requirements, 2.3% of the events for ψ(2S)(ℓ + ℓ − )π − and 7.1% for ψ(2S)(J/ψπ + π − )π − contain more than one B candidate.
For these events, we choose the B candidate whose M bc is closest to the nominal B meson mass.
To suppress continuum background, events having a ratio of the second to zeroth Fox-Wolfram moments [21] R 2 > 0.5 are rejected.

Large B → (J/ψ, ψ(2S))X MC samples corresponding to 3.86 × 10 10 generic BB events are used for the background study, because backgrounds predominantly come from B decays into final states having J/ψ → ℓ + ℓ − or ψ(2S) → ℓ + ℓ − .
We find that the dominant background comes from B − → ψ(2S)K − where the kaon is misidentified as a pion.
This decay mode makes a peak at ∆E ∼ −0.07 GeV.
Other backgrounds originate from random combinations of ψ(2S) and π − candidates (combinatorial background) and do not form any peaking structure in the ∆E projection of the MC sample.
Studies of ∆M and ℓ + ℓ − invariant mass data sidebands support this assumption.
We extract the signal yield by performing an unbinned extended maximum likelihood fit to the ∆E distribution of the selected B candidates.

where N is the total number of candidate events; N S , N BK and N C denote the number of signal, background from B − → ψ(2S)K − and combinatorial background events, respectively.

The modeling PDF's include a sum of two Gaussians for the signal (P S (∆E i )), a sum of two bifurcated Gaussians for the B − → ψ(2S)K − background (P BK (∆E i )) and a second-order polynomial for other backgrounds (P C (∆E i )).
In this study the B − → ψ(2S)K − decay mode is used as a control sample, as well as the denominator of the relative branching fraction ratio
The B − → ψ(2S)π − signal shape is fixed to that obtained from the B − → ψ(2S)K − control sample.
The B − → ψ(2S)K − background shape is determined from the MC sample after applying a correction for the difference between data and MC.
For the smooth combinatorial background, parameters of the second-order polynomial are floated in the fit.

We perform a simultaneous fit to all the considered ψ(2S) decay modes to obtain a common branching fraction, taking into account different detection efficiencies for each sub-decay mode and detector configuration.
The efficiencies are determined from signal MC samples after  applying the correction factors taking into account the data and MC differences as described later.
In the fit, the yield of B − → ψ(2S)K − (background) and the yield and polynomial parameters of the combinatorial backgrounds are floated for each decay mode separately.
The fit gives a branching fraction of (2.44 ± 0.22 ± 0.20) × 10 −5 , where the first error is statistical and the second is systematic.
Equal production of neutral and charged B meson pairs in the Υ(4S) decay is assumed.
We use the J/ψ → e + e − , J/ψ → µ + µ − , ψ(2S) → J/ψπ + π − , ψ(2S) → e + e − and ψ(2S) → µ + µ − intermediate branching fractions from Ref.
Separate fits to the four sub-modes are also performed.
The results are shown in Fig. 2 and summarized in Table I.
The yields are calculated from the obtained branching fractions and efficiencies.
The efficiencies listed in Table I are weighted averages of the two separate data sets.
For all sub-modes, we observe signals with more than 5σ statistical significance and the branching fractions agree well with one another.
The statistical significance is defined as −2 ln (L 0 /L max ) where L max (L 0 ) denotes the likelihood value at the maximum (with the signal yield fixed to zero).
A correction for small differences in the signal detection efficiency calculated from signal MC and data has been applied for the pion identification requirement, muon identification and ∆M .
Uncertainties on these corrections are included in the systematic error.

The J/ψ → ℓ + ℓ − and e + e − → e + e − ℓ + ℓ − samples are used to estimate the lepton identification correction and uncertainty whereas the pion (kaon) identification correction and uncertainty are determined from a D * + → D 0 (K − π + )π + sample.

A correction factor for the ∆M requirement is determined from the B − → ψ(2S)K − sample and is estimated by taking the ratio of yields from data and MC for tight (0.578 GeV/c 2 < ∆M < 0.598 GeV/c 2 ) and loose (0.570 GeV/c 2 < ∆M < 0.610 GeV/c 2 ) selection cuts.
The fitting procedure is checked using signal and B → (J/ψ, ψ(2S))X MC samples and no significant bias is found.

The signal yield systematic uncertainty is calculated by varying each fixed parameter in the fit by ±1σ, and then taking the sum in quadrature of the deviations of the signal yield from the nominal value.
The total systematic uncertainty assigned to the yield estimation is 3.5%.
The uncertainties due to the daughter branching fractions amount to 3.4%.
The uncertainty on the tracking efficiency is estimated to be 1.2% per track and 5.0% in total.
Systematic errors have been estimated by taking into account whether the particular error is correlated or uncorrelated and then combining them with the proper weights.
All the systematic uncertainties are summarized in Table II.
The total systematic error of 8.4% is the sum in quadrature of all the uncertainties.

We extract branching fractions for B + and B − samples separately using the same procedure as described above, except the polynomial background shape is fixed to that obtained in the previous fit to the total B ± → ψ(2S)π ± yield.
We obtain A = 0.022 ± 0.085 ± 0.016 (3) with corresponding signal yields of 89 ± 11 and 93 ± 11 for B + and B − , respectively.

Here the systematic error includes contributions from the uncertainty on the yield extraction method, charge asymmetry in the pion identification efficiency as well as a possible detector bias and a possible difference between B + and B − signal shape parameters.
Among all these uncertainties, the only nonnegligible one is a possible detector bias: it is estimated to be 0.016 from a study of B − → J/ψK − .
We also measure the ratio of B(B − → ψ(2S)π − ) and B(B − → ψ(2S)K − ).
In a study using large B → (J/ψ, ψ(2S))X MC samples, the amount of background for B − → ψ(2S)(ℓ + ℓ − )K − is found to be negligible.

On the other hand, in the case of B − → ψ(2S)(J/ψπ + π − )K − , the decay mode B − → J/ψK 1 (1270) − as well as B − → J/ψπ + π − K − appear as peaking backgrounds since they  have the same final state as the signal.
The background estimation is performed using the ∆M data sideband defined as 0.51 GeV/c 2 < ∆M < 0.57 GeV/c 2 and 0.61 GeV/c 2 < ∆M < 0.67 GeV/c 2 .
We obtain 7.2±2.7 events for B − → ψ(2S)(J/ψ(ee)ππ)K − and 9.4 ± 2.7 events for B − → ψ(2S)(J/ψ(µµ)ππ)K − when scaled to the signal region.
These backgrounds are subtracted from the appropriate signal yields.
A simultaneous unbinned extended maximum-likelihood fit gives a branching fraction of (6.12 ± 0.09)×10 −4 and corresponding signal yield of 4720 ± 69, where the error is statistical only.
The resulting fit is shown in Fig. 3.
The branching fraction is in good agreement with our previous measurement [4] and the world-average [20].
We obtain the ratio of B(B − → ψ(2S)π − ) and B(B − → ψ(2S)K − ) to be B(B − → ψ(2S)π − ) B(B − → ψ(2S)K − ) = (3.99 ± 0.36 ± 0.17)%,
which is consistent with the expectations of the factorization hypothesis.
Many sources of systematic errors cancel in the ratio of the branching fractions.

Contributions to the systematic error come from the uncertainty in pion identification, signal extraction method, MC statistics from B − → ψ(2S)π − (K − ) decay, kaon identification and uncertainty on the background estimation from B − → ψ(2S)K − decay.
The total uncertainty is 4.2%.
In summary, we report the first observation of the decay B − → ψ(2S)π − using 657×10 6  .
No significant direct CP -violating charge asymmetry is observed in B − → ψ(2S)π − .
The ratio of branching fractions is (3.99 ± 0.36 ± 0.17)% which is consistent with the theoretical prediction based on factorization [11].
